messageBody:
>>>>> "Theodore" == Theodore Norvell <theo@...> writes:

Theodore> On Mon, 18 Mar 2002, nsparis wrote:
>> Let me make it clearer...The exception is thrown, which is what
>> is suppose to happen, but instead of being printed out in JUnit
>> it crashes JUnit. I.e. JUnit isnt automatically catching it
>> and flagging it as an error for the test case.
>>
>> What do I need to change so that JUnit catches the exception
>> and reports it as an error?

Theodore> Here's an idea that might work. In your new thread catch
Theodore> the errors and failures and put them in the TestResult.
Theodore> The problem is that it is not clear how to find the
Theodore> TestResult using a standard TestCase. Below is a stab
Theodore> at how it might be done.

I did something like this for a socket server test I was writing. It
is not as robust as it should be, as it doesn't handle ThreadDeath,
etc, but it worked for my purposes.

Here is the pertinent code:

================================
import junit.framework.*;

public class SocketServerTest extends TestCase {
private TestResult result;

public void run(TestResult result) {
this.result = result;
super.run(result);
}

private void runServer() {
Runnable r = new Runnable() {
public void run() {
try {
server.acceptConnection();
}
catch (Exception e) {
result.addError(SocketServerTest.this, e);
}
}
};
t = new Thread(r);
t.start();
}
}
===============================

By doing this, the framework just works. Note that if I wanted to
catch test Failures, my exception handling in the runServer method
would need to be a little more complicated.
